abstract.p: Stanley Herz letter, commenting on August 25 article on airport congestion, says tax should be added to peak travel times, encouraging passengers to fly during off-peak periods

block.p: Re ''Doing the Math of Air Delays'' (news article, Aug. 25):

A tax should be added to peak travel times, encouraging passengers to fly during off-peak periods. Although the financial burden will fall primarily on business travelers, the offset will be spending less time in airports. As an executive-search consultant who travels frequently, I would gladly pay a premium to be more productive.
Re ''Doing the Math of Air Delays'' (news article, Aug. 25):

A tax should be added to peak travel times, encouraging passengers to fly during off-peak periods. Although the financial burden will fall primarily on business travelers, the offset will be spending less time in airports. As an executive-search consultant who travels frequently, I would gladly pay a premium to be more productive.

Tax revenues themselves should be assigned to further reducing flying pressure. One use would be to improve rail alternatives for shorter distances. Another would be to subsidize fares at less crowded times and less crowded airports, further easing congestion.
Nor will only fliers benefit. If we can reduce airport congestion, think how the highways and road patterns will also benefit.
